questions.question: Which coaching model offers the highest degree of scalability by decoupling the coach's direct time from revenue generation?
options: One-on-one intensive coaching
Asynchronous digital products and memberships
Small group coaching (4-6 participants)
Retainer-based executive consulting
questions.explanation: Digital products and memberships allow for 'infinite' scaling because the cost of serving an additional customer is near zero once the content is created.

questions.question: According to the '70% Rule' discussed in Lesson 2, when is the optimal time for a founder to delegate a specific task to a team member?
options: When the team member can perform the task 100% as well as the founder
When the founder no longer enjoys performing the task
When a team member can perform the task at least 70% as well as the founder
Only when the task is 70% automated by software
questions.explanation: The 70% rule suggests delegating when someone else can perform a task to 70% of your standard, allowing you to focus on high-level strategy while they bridge the remaining 30% through experience.

questions.question: In strategic marketing, what is the industry-standard 'Golden Ratio' for Customer Lifetime Value (LTV) to Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)?
questions.explanation: A 3:1 LTV to CAC ratio is considered the benchmark for a healthy, growing business, indicating that a customer is worth three times what it cost to acquire them.

questions.question: A burnout coach spends $5,000 on a targeted ad campaign resulting in 20 new clients for a $1,500 program. What is the Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)?
questions.explanation: CAC is calculated by dividing total marketing spend ($5,000) by the number of new customers acquired (20), which equals $250.

questions.question: Which financial phenomenon occurs when a coaching business grows so quickly that it runs out of cash despite being profitable on paper?
options: Revenue plateau
Overtrading
Margin compression
Asset depreciation
questions.explanation: Overtrading happens when a business expands operations too rapidly, exhausting cash reserves to fund growth before the revenue from that growth is actually collected.

questions.question: When leveraging technology for scalability, what is the primary purpose of a 'Zapier' or 'Make' integration in a coaching stack?
options: To host video coaching calls
To automate data transfer between disconnected software applications
To provide AI-driven sentiment analysis on client journals
To manage the legal payroll of international employees
questions.explanation: Integration tools like Zapier connect different platforms (e.g., CRM to Email Marketing), reducing manual administrative work and human error during scaling.

questions.question: In the context of strategic partnerships, what does a 'White Label' agreement typically involve?
options: A coach selling another company's product under the coach's own branding
Two coaches sharing the same office space to save on overhead
A legal disclaimer stating the coach is not a medical professional
A referral fee paid for every client sent to a psychologist
questions.explanation: White labeling allows a coach to use a third-party's curriculum or platform and present it as their own, facilitating rapid scaling of content offerings.

questions.question: To protect Intellectual Property (IP) when hiring contractors to develop course materials, which legal clause is most critical?
options: Non-Compete Clause
Indemnification Clause
Work for Hire / IP Assignment
Force Majeure
questions.explanation: A 'Work for Hire' or IP Assignment clause ensures that the business—not the contractor—owns the rights to the materials created during the contract.

questions.question: The 'Founder's Trap' in a scaling burnout practice is best described as:
options: The founder becoming burned out by their own clients
The business being unable to function or grow because the founder is the only delivery mechanism
Setting prices too low to cover the cost of a new office
Failing to pay quarterly estimated taxes
questions.explanation: The Founder's Trap occurs when the brand is so tied to the individual founder that the business cannot scale beyond the founder's personal hours and energy.

questions.question: Research on business sustainability suggests that systemizing 80% of repetitive administrative tasks can increase a practitioner's coaching capacity by what percentage range?
options: Over 100%
questions.explanation: Data indicates that aggressive systemization of back-end tasks (billing, scheduling, onboarding) typically yields a 30-40% increase in direct client-facing capacity.
